results.title: How do children think?
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Discovery and Experience”.
Discusses Piaget’s research and theories of the main periods of development in children. To advance beyond the stage of primitive concrete operations, children need opportunities for the kind of work they do in primary schools, based on activity, discussion, and the growth of social relationships.

results.title: Movement in time and space
results.creator_credit: Eileen Molony and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Discovery and Experience”.
The outside world consists of experiences rather than objects, to the young child. Socialisation of the school child takes place only after a series of explorations and discoveries about being a person. Music, movement, and drama once considered recreational functions, are now regarded as ways of exploring space, time and personality.

results.title: Finding out
results.creator_credit: George Luger, Eileen Molony and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Discovery and Experience”.
Educational research into the mental processes of young children has confirmed the value of growing emphasis on activity, experience and exploration for primary school children. Designed primarily for parents and students training to be teachers.

results.title: Maths is a monster
results.creator_credit: Eileen Molony and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery and Experience”.
Considers the effect the research of Jean Piaget has had on the teaching of mathematics. Primary school children think in concrete terms so the lessons of modern maths are drawn from life inside and outside school. Shows children of different abilities tackling various kinds of mathematical work, discovering relations between concepts and developing abstract thinking abilities.

results.title: The Changeover
results.creator_credit: Eileen Molony and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery and Experience”.
As there is growing emphasis in education on what a child does rather than what the teacher says, a gradual change in teaching methods and class management has taken place. Discusses new concepts in teaching, teacher training, classroom organisation and the attitude of the teacher to the children. Suitable for teacher training.

results.title: What's visceral learning, anyway ?
results.creator_credit: Richard Handford, David Taylor and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery”.
Describes the experiments of Dr Neal Miller and his team at Rockefeller University in visceral learning. Visceral learning concerns the control of the heart, the stomach and the intestines at will.

results.title: Grass
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery”.
Australian scientists are looking at how the use of marijuana affects the mind and body of the user. Researchers and users are shown here examining what happens to a person who is under the influence of marijuana. They investigate the claims that are often made about this drug - that marijuana leads to the use of hard drugs. Marijuana is now illegal in most countries, but the marijuana explosion of the 60s and 70s has led to a growing campaign supporting legislation.

results.title: Aurora
results.creator_credit: Peter Jones, David Taylor and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery”.
An investigation of the mystery surrounding the Aurora Borealis. An Australian physicist, Dr Robert Eather, at Boston College, Massachusetts has developed a method of filming the aurora in color.

results.title: An Eye for the job
results.creator_credit: Nigel Miller, Kevin Sim and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery”.
A documentary about the quiet revolution in the operating theatre. The surgeon has now harnessed his skills to the microscope, and operations of the most minute detail are achieved with microsurgery. Depicts five case studies - a blind painter is made to see again, a deaf grandmother can hear again, a worker’s torn off hand is restored, a man’s severed thumb is replaced by his big toe, and a young woman has her fallopian tubes untied.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nigel Miller, Kevin Sim and Yorkshire Television
